column4: The lack of reproducibility in simulation studies is a significant issue in the transportation literature
column5: I have invested considerable time and effort in attempting to reproduce existing studies (which could have been avoided, e.g. with better documentation)
column6: There is a need for greater transparency from researchers regarding their code, data, and simulation models
column7: New publications should be required to include a basic online repository and data availability statement
column8: I cannot publish due to legal constraints (e.g., data privacy, intellectual property rights)
column9: I have concerns about the quality of reliability of my simulations
column10: I lack confidence and/or feel vulnerable in sharing code, data, or models publicly
column11: I have time constraints (that limit efforts in preparing repositories and managing data-sharing agreements to the desired level)
column12: I lack knowledge about tools and best practices for managing repositories
column13: I believe sharing data upon request is sufficient (e.g., via email)
column14: I fear transparency might hinder chances of publication acceptance
column15: Other researchers fear transparency might hinder chances of publication acceptance
column16: I intentionally withhold materials to maintain a competitive advantage
column17: Other researchers intentionally withhold materials to maintain what they believe to be a competitive advantage
column19: Researchers should publish data (raw or processed)
column21: Researchers should publish software / source code
column22: Researchers should publish a comprehensive online appendix alongside each study, detailing the methodologies
column23:
Journals should mandate data availability statements and repositories 
to ensure reproducibility (e.g. GitHub, BitBucket, SourceForge, Mendeley)
column24: Funding agencies should require detailed reproducibility plans in grant proposals
column25: Our research group has implemented some type of measure to enhance reproducibility in our work
column26: Further suggestions you might think of
column29: 3) Where is your research organization located?

column18: Data privacy and IP can be a big issue. For example, one project is funded by a company, in which case, the code is not the IP of the researcher alone, and thus not being able to be made available. The research cannot be published in a journal that requires open-sourcing of the code and/or data.

for the last two questions: depends what you share
and depends which phenomena you are claiming/ investigating as core contribution of your work. if simulation is the tool; or a end product of your research, in a sense.
column26:
it depends!
a data availability statement is easy; this is already enforced.
but a forced repository to ensure reproducibility is a completely different thing!

column26: things should be transparent, but no need to attach absolutely everything to a publication

column30: Yeah, regarding the survey it will be helpful if you explain what is a simulation/model for you. I transport research and in the other fields we have tones of different simulations/models. Some of them can be done in open source software or code but others are better in paid software. I have experience with both of them. Nowadays I am doing all my research base in open source data and software consequently it was difficult to possitionate in the survey.

column26: While I do not necessarily have strong opinion about all simulation codes, I strongly believe that AI/ML related algorithm code and data have to be made publicly available.
column30: Rather than just making data and code publicly available, some effort should also be spent in collecting and organizing different algorithm codes into a common repository under different categories, e.g., ramp metering, traffic signal control, etc.

column18: Doing research is often a 'messy' process, so that generating a repository that people can actually use is extremely difficult. Just making data and codes available online does not necessarily imply that other researchers can actually reproduce a study. There is so much tacit knowledge that evolves while conducting a research that is difficult to describe, let alone make accessible. A 'messy' process does not imply a non-rigorous approach. Exactly the opposite: preliminary results raise questions, calling for additional analyses, transposing of variables, other estimations methods etc. There are many small steps that are easily forgotten when making materials available online.
column26: If making materials available online is required by funders and by leading journals, it will gradually become standard practice, and routines of doing so will develop. It forces a level playing field: everybody will have to invest time in this (and funders will have to fund this activity too).
column30: Good study! Straightforward yet relevant questions! Good luck!

column26: Funding agencies need to follow through at the end of the grant to ensure promises are kept.
